title: People Fly Too
body:
Diane held her mother's hand joyfully. Her pink hoodie buried her jet black hair. Blue eyes were hardly noticed beneath her midnight bangs. She held a smile upon her face as the two of them made their way to the park.

Her mother kept Diane close as she sighed in content. Just a bit ahead was a colorful stand, which they attended everyday. Bright balls filled with helium were attached to the little stop labled 'Balloons'.

After they were close enough, Diane sprinted to the balloon stand. The owner, Lucus, smiled at the young girl. "Came back for another?" He asked, letting out a laugh. "Pretty soon your house will go flying, if it hasn't happened already."

Diane laughed as well, before her mother made it to the stand. "Good morning Lucus," her mother said to the man.

He handed Diane a lavender balloon, which was the only one left. "Good morning Kate. So the house hasn't flown to space yet?"

"Nope, not yet," she replied. After digging in her purse, Diane's mother handed him five dollars to pay. Her mother bent down to Diane's level with a kind smile. "Would you like me to tie that to your wrist?"

Diane smiled as she nodded. "Yes please," she replied and held her wrist out patiently.

Later, the mother returned home with her daughter. Diane ran to her room to release her balloon with the many others. "Diane, are you ready for lunch?" Her mother asked as she walked into her child's room. She let out a sigh seeing the mess of clothes on the floor and deflated balloons in a pile. "You know sweetie, we have to get rid of these old ones. You want room for more right?"

Diane sighed and nodded as she began cleaning up the pile. She let out a deep sigh before smiling and carrying them downstairs.

Her mother sighed and began to set the table for their lunch.

Diane frowned before she began eating a grilled cheese sandwich that was just brought off the stove. "Mommy?"

Her mother stopped eating and looked up and across the table to her daughter. She felt a chill run down her spine as her daughter had a smile almost unsettling. "Yes Diane?" She asked after finishing the food in her mouth.

"Can people fly?" She asked, sounding completely innocent even though her smile was terrifying.

"Of course not sweetie, we're not birds," her mother replied as she shook her head gently. "You should know this."

Diane frowned as she looked at her mother. She stood up and walked to the stairs. "Silly mommy, you just haven't tried yet." And with that, Diane walked to her room. "I'll prove you wrong."

That night Diane smiled widely as she looked at her mother in awe, Lucus stood next to her. "I told mommy people can fly. She just hasn't tried yet."

Her mother was hanging from the ceiling by balloons that had once been in her room. Diane shook her head lightly as she giggled happily.

The next day Lucus was standing at a balloon stand with a wide smile and Diane stood next to him. A little boy ran over and bought a balloon from them happily.

"Hey, did you know people fly too?" Diane asked the little boy before his eyes lit up in awe.
